column4: I've got a mini-itx mobo w/Atom 330 and NVidia ION, running lucid 64-bit. I'm getting segfaults and weird crashes (eg. http://pastebin.com/mfhVwtXM), and I'm having trouble pinning it down. I've been running kernel compiles (make -j4) for a few hours without any crashes, so I *think* it's not a ram/cpu problem. Aone got any ideas?
Allthough I would think of a RAM/timing/cooling problem.
If you have two RAM modules, try removing one and test if the system is stable then. if not, replace the one with the other

I know. But I can't reproduce it by kernel compiles. The load is at ~6 right now, and has been for hours. It hasn't failed at all. If I start X on the other hand, it appears to be a lot less cooperative.
Use slowest RAM timings, if your BIOS allow to adjust this.
RAM/CPU or thermical problems are the most difficult one to point out :-(
Any safe way to reproduce that segmentation faults?
thanks, don't know why I didn't think of that. I'll try single dimm first. I've tried memtest86+ overnight, but nothing showed up (but that's not exactly foolproof)
Sadly, memtest(+) is no safe way of detecting flat ram.
There's no easily reproducible way, no. It appears to be pretty random
I know, I've had better success using heavy kernel compiles.
If it shows the same defective adresses in several runs, you have a flat chip.
But if it detects nothing, this doesn't mean your RAM is really okay....
I know.
Anyway, it would appear that the worst thing I can do is start XBMC with VDPAU
Maybe removing one chip helps to find out. Try using another RAM slot as well, maybe some "dusty" contacts
Not really that many to choose between, only two on this mini-itx mobo ;)
XMBC? OK, I'm using VDR with VDPAU :-)

Don't watch much live tv, so VDR isn't that interesting :-P But XBMC appears to make the segfaults appear a lot more frequently. I'll rip out a dimm and try first, then adjust timings. If that doesn't help, what then? :)
Next thing would be heavy cooling
Not to say to put it in the fridge, cool it down and run it with the cables through the fridge door.
Of course only mainboard, not harddisk/power suppl
There are camping cooling boxes. Put in some ice or cooling accus to get the temperature low.
That's easier than putting everything into the fridge.
